_exec_summary.SummaryText:
City of Jamestown, Kentucky
Water Treatment Plant

Executive Summary:
Facility and Regulated Substances Handled:
The City of Jamestown Water Treatment Plant (WTP) is a publicly owned treatment works which is responsible for sterilization and supply of potable water for the city of Jamestown, Kentucky.  The WTP stores and uses chlorine for the sterilization process.  One-ton cylinders of chlorine are stored on site with a maximum inventory of 3 cylinders or 6,000 pounds.  

Chlorine is stored at ambient temperatures as liquid under pressure of 90-160 psi.  Although stored as a liquid, chlorine will vaporize upon release to the atmosphere, making the release of the chemical in the gaseous state the greatest risk.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:
As an additional source of reference in the event of a release, the City of Jamestown WTP shall developed Chemical Process Safety Management Plan (PSM) according to OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.119.  

Critical to preventing a release is continual employee training in handling the chemicals both in bulk and process quantities, in the specific hazards and properties of each chemical, and the proper operation of chemical process and processing equipment.  This includes ensuring that contractors and their employees are fully aware of the potential dangers.

Also necessary is adherence to a preventative maintenance program including regular equipment inspection and repair of all process and safety equipment.   

Five Year Accident History:
No accidents have occurred at this site in the last five years.

Emergency Response Program:
The Jamestown WTP and Fire Department have coordinated in the preparation of emergency response procedures.  In the event of a catastrophic release of chlorine, the water treatment plant employees will evacuate the premises.  The Jamestown Fire Department will be immediately notified of the release.  The Jamestown Fire Department and WTP faculty will ass

ist in the evacuation of the surrounding effected areas. The Fire Department has conducted a site survey. 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:
All safety management procedures, plans, employee training, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, and process safety information shall be review and revised on a regular basis.   Each review will be performed at the specific time frames set forth in the Process Safety Management Plan.
